awd_titl_txt: Effects of Victimization on Engagement and Expression
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the effect of severe crime victimization on the mobilization of friends and family.  Specifically, it investigates why some of these individuals mobilize and others do not and for those who do, why they mobilize in the way that they do.  Prior research shows that victimization of a friend or family member affects public activity.  In this project, interviews with such individuals are used to research how these events have affected their psychological, social, and public lives.  Findings will be useful to social service agencies, decision makers, and others seeking to improve outcomes in this area.

Hypotheses that the forms of victimization will affect responses, conditional on demographic characteristics, will be investigated by identifying 36 cases of victimization and interviewing 5 to 15 individuals per case.  These interviews will be spread across three different categories of victimization in two locations with different cultures. The interviews will be analyzed to engage questions regarding why people participate in the movements they do, the social psychological precursors to and consequences of public engagement, and the relationship between public culture and public outcomes.  In doing so, the project will lay intellectual groundwork for scholars interested in analyzing the import of victimization, including but extending beyond the victimization investigated here.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported research into, broadly speaking, the relationship between victimization and political engagement (including how direct experiences of past victimization inform political views and political activities as well as how concerns regarding future victimization relate to political engagement) through the construction of original datasets of in-depth interviews and archival material. Academic presentations and publications from this award have contributed to understandings of: the role of racial disparities in cumulative trauma among crime victims in shaping political claims; racial and gender disparities in framing need and deservingness for redress of crime victims; the relationship between partisanship and gender; the micro-level dynamics of conspiracism as a political epistemology; and the role of self-defense in American democratic culture. Over the course of the award period, results have been presented at venues such as the Law & Society Annual Meeting, the American Sociological Association Annual Meeting, as well as a variety of invited lectures at US universities; peer-reviewed publications from this award include articles in Social Problems and Social Forces (top journals within sociology) and a research monograph at Princeton University Press. In addition to dissemination within academic outlets, results from this award have been shared in the public sphere through a variety of op-eds (e.g., LA Times, New York Times, Washington Post), media interviews (e.g., PBS, USA Today) and public appearances (e.g., Aspen Ideas Festival, the Texas Tribune Festival, the LA Times Festival of Books). Over the course of the funded period, this award has also provided undergraduate RAs with training in database construction and preliminary analysis, and it has provided graduate RAs with training in interview transcription, database construction, qualitative analysis (including training with qualitative data analysis software), and dissemination of results (including peer-reviewed publications and oral presentations).
